title: 5G Communications: What companies are leading in 5G technologies? - Quora

response.answer_text: I recently did some market research in 5G and converted that into a guide which has described the research of some big telecom companies. The guide has more than 10 companies who intensely research on 5G technology. And the company which seemed leading on 5G to me is Ericsson. Why? You asked. Here is why. Ericsson claims to be the only vendor that is currently working in all continents to make 5G a global standard for the next generation of wireless technology. Their 5G radio prototypes are the first products designed to enable operators to conduct live field trials in their own networks which helps operators to get a greater understanding for the potential of 5G in their own networks and environments. Given their expertise in the 5G domain, many companies across the globe will collaborate with Ericsson. They have already performed several trials by collaborating with domestic vendors. In February, Ericsson and Korea Telecom with Intel conducted a 5G trial connecting a car to a live 5G network right in the center of Seoul. In the dense urban environment, 4K video was streamed to and from the car, giving an idea of how 5G will change the experience for car passengers.Last year, the company joined with Celcom Axiata Berhad for first ever 5G testing in Malaysia. It’s also the first 5G trial conducted on the 28 GHz band in South East Asia. The trial showcased Celcom’s commitment to providing the best services to Malaysia.Batelco and Ericsson have conducted Bahrain’s first 5G trial which aims to drive innovation for IoT applications using the next-generation mobile network technology. The trial was conducted at Batelco’s Headquarters during their 5G Forum event and demonstrated 5G capabilities in a real-world environment and over a live network, including tests on speed, latency, and beam steering, reaching a record speed of 25 Gbps.Multiple companies teamed up to make 5G available in some cities. Tallink, Telia, Ericsson, and Intel have created a 5G test and exploration area at the Port of Tallinn. The trail network is delivering internet to the commercial, passenger cruise ships while in the port. With million passengers annually on its Baltic sea routes, Tallink is one of the largest ocean transport companies of Europe.In India, Ericsson partnered with Indian telecom Bharti Airtel for 5G.Ericsson showcased the first-ever live 5G demonstration in India. The demonstration using Ericsson’s 5G test bed and 5G New Radio (NR) delivered a throughput of 5.7 Gbps and ultra-low latency of 3 milliseconds. According to a latest Ericsson study, 5G technology will enable a $27.3 Billion revenue potential for the Indian telecom operators by 2026.Ericsson connection also reached the Pacific region where they made an alliance with Australian telecom NBN for kicking off 5G trials in Melbourne. “As with any new technology, there have been claims made about how 5G will impact the fixed broadband market,” Owen said during the CommsDay Summit in Sydney.While Ericsson is making several alliances, it is also working on making 5G’s speed better. In a partnership with SK Telecom and BMW Korea, Ericsson used advanced 5G technology to track a connected car traveling up to 170 km/hour to demonstrate data transmission speeds on a 5G network. Using advanced beamforming and beam tracking, the high-performance network connection supported point-to-point data transmission from a connected car traveling up to 170 kilometers per hour with downlink speeds of 3.6 Gbps.Ericsson is partnering with the Fraunhofer Institute for Production Technology to develop so-called blade integrated disks, or blisks, for Germany-based jet engine manufacturer MTU Aero Engines.Ericsson recently signed a 3-year deal with Movistar Argentina to transform its Radio Access Network to expand network coverage and improve the mobile broadband experience to its customers.Ericsson also plans to invest in the Indian market as for them it is a crucial market for their business. They will start deploying the 5G networks in India in 2019 and major deployment will begin in 2020.Moreover, the company also secures all the research and inventions they are making. For example, for securing their inventions in 5G, Ericsson filed a landmark patent application for 5G with WIPO and USPTO. The patent application, which combines the work of 130 Ericsson inventors, is the largest in cellular communications in terms of the number of inventors, anywhere in the world. It shows the industry how Ericsson has approached 5G standardization with a comprehensive view that connects individual inventions in a complete 5G telecommunications network, rather than focusing on any smaller individual inventions. In a recent event at 5G MENA 2018, Ericsson presented its latest 5G strategy which would bring together telecom operators and IoT specialists across the region. All these research and working show that they are leading in 5G. Still, if you really want to know about other, you can read other 5G major companies’ research.

Huawei is an important participant in the global 5G construction. Recently, Xinsheng Community disclosed that 1 367 5G base stations were built in 19 days by LG U+Korea. This is the fastest 5G base station construction in history. The equipment supplier for LG U+5G base station and planning and construction service is from China, named Huawei.  5G technology is in the commercial sprint stage, and this year will be the key year of 5G commerce. Once it is applied and popularized on a large scale, it is of great social significance. As the world's largest telecommunications equipment manufacturer, Huawei attracts attention from all walks of life in 5G progress. At a 5G conference at the end of January this year, Huawei launched a 5G base station-oriented Tiangu chip, and demonstrated 5G base station, as well as brought 5G terminal chip Balong 5000, 5G mobile phone will also be released on this year's MWC (Mobile World Congress). For Huawei, standing in the new era of 5G, it explores 5G applications with all walks of life, creates new business models and jointly builds an interconnected intelligent world. It has set off a wave of 5G construction all over the world. More than 30 5G commercial contracts have been signed in various countries around the world, and more than 25,000 5G base stations have been sent to the world. On December 1, 2018, the three major Korean operators announced that 5G was officially commercialized. As of the day of the 5G commercial release in Korea, 5804 5G base stations had been deployed, of which 4133 were LG U +. China Huawei is the equipment supplier that provides 5G base station and planning and construction services for LG U+. As of December 19, 2018, LG U+has built 5,500 5G base stations. From December 1 to December 19, 4133 base stations were disclosed. In 19 days, LG U+built 1,367 5G base stations. This is the fastest construction speed of 5G base stations in history, while the number of LG U+competitors is less than 1,000. His speed is so fast that his opponents are caught by surprise. The integration of 5G technology, especially with AI technology, will promote the digital transformation of society. It can be said that Huawei plays an important role in the global communication market. Many countries have expressed that if Huawei's entry is restricted, it will affect the whole nation's communication network construction. It can be seen that the global 5G construction of Huawei is of great significance.

Today’s IT industry is split between those who worry that it’s already too late to catch the 5G gravy train and those who still think they still have plenty of time. This confusion is partly due to the mixed signals sent by the telco giants, but it is also due to lack of a clear timetable for the rollout of next generation mobile technology. In fact, “5G” is just a marketing term that covers a wide range of new mobile technologies. Back in early 2012, the standards committee of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) - originally the International Telegraph Union - called for a network capacity of up to 20 gigabits. To put that in context: while LTE can theoretically achieve speeds of around 300Mbps, in reality, we are not likely to get more than around 42Mbps; standard 4G has real-world speeds of just around 14Mbps. 5G trials are taking place today, with Verizon in the US, for example, demonstrating that its technology can achieve 30-50 times faster download speeds than currently possible with 4G. That would enable you to download a full movie in around 15 seconds, versus around 6 minutes on 4G. Most telcos and other providers are talking about 2020 as the likely date for commercial availability of 5G, but some seem intent on stealing a march on the competition. While Chinese manufacturer ZTE was the first handset manufacturer to showcase a 5G smartphone at GSMA Mobile World Congress in 2017, Lenovo has eyes set on 5G smartphone leadership, based on chipsets provided by Qualcomm, an American company. Has the future already begun? And will 5G really herald a new era, much like the introduction of the internet itself more than a quarter of a century ago? One thing is clear: By using a much wider range of frequencies in a more flexible fashion, 5G has the potential to connect billions of mobile devices. Most of them will not be smartphones at all, but rather sensors and actuators included in a plethora of IoT devices, including automobiles, trains and planes. Engineers are already busy building robots and entire production lines with connection capabilities that rival today’s fixed-line systems, only faster and more securely. 5G is the first mobile standard conceived expressly with machine-to-machine (M2M) applications in mind. Theoretically, at least, this could prove a gigantic shot in the arm for autonomous vehicles and other systems, including “smart factories”.

Huawei is undoubtedly one of the market leaders of 5G technologies with its advanced equipment and infrastructures related to 5G technology. Huawei has invested a lot of money in the research of 5G technology and has gained a patent for some of its key technologies. It has also hired experts from all over the world in order to undergo extensive research and set the standards for the next generation 5G technology.  Image credit: ZDNet Moreover, Huawei has also planned to involve AI (Artificial Intelligence) as an integral part of the 5G strategy implemented by the company. The other two companies leading in the field of 5G technologies are Nokia (NOK) and Ericsson (ERIC) and these two companies are likely to benefit the most after the recent ban of 5G equipment manufactured by Huawei by the US Government and share prices of these two companies have gone up substantially after the announcement of the ban on Huawei. However, neither 5G service or 5GPhones are available everywhere just yet, and release dates are different for every carrier in the US, Verizon: Fixed and mobile 5G is life in a few areasAT&T: Mobile 5G for select customers in 19 cities; wider coverage in 2019T-Mobile: Commercial 5G launch in the second half of 2019; nationwide coverage expected in 2020 Hope it helps! OKportal Technology

As the world remained fixated on the launch of Apple’s iPhone 8 in Sep 2017, a quiet mobile revolution has just begun. Huawei had launched the world’s first 5G network with Deutche Telecom in Germany on 1st Sep 2017.[1] Throughout the dawn of the 21st century, we went though the 2G(digitalization of voice and music), 3G (multimedia communications feature) and 4G(wireless broadband) mobile revolution with the core communications technology monopolized by a few European and United States' companies such as Qualcomm, Verizon and Ericsson. China became the first Asian country to break this communications technology and standards oligopoly held by a handful of US and Europe companies with the launch of 5G (high frequency broadcast) network which can transfer data at 100 times 4G’s capacity at the same speed. Huawei recently unveiled its Kirin 970 chipset[2] which is equipped with the world's first 5G baseband, powering its mobile network throughput at twice the speed of Qualcomm's best Snapdragon chipset. The 970 chipset has 5.5billion Transistors which rivals Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835, and does the job with higher efficiency and less heat generated.[3] 5G consumes less power than 4G for a similar amount of data transfer, can has data 10 times the data transfer capacity of 4G chipset. More wireless products could become mainstream and practical for consumer usage such as smart home appliances and mobile accessories. The Kirin 970 is also the world's first AI chipset, with a neural processing unit( NPU ) with processing power twice that of other equivalent CPU, while consuming 50 times less power, which means you can take 1000 pictures on your mobile phone and consumes only 19% of the mobile phone battery, with data transfer capacity and speed 10 times that of a 4G chipset.  Footnotes[1] Deutsche Telekom launches "Europe's first" 5G network with Huawei[2] IFA 2017: Huawei reveals low-power Kirin 970 mobile AI chipset[3] Huawei to unveil Kirin 970 SoC with AI Unit, 5.5 billion transistors and 1.2 Gbps LTE speed at IFA 2017

What is 5G Technology?5G Technology is the 5th generation digital cellular network technology. The millimeter-wave of the 5G enables to provide the speed of 1-2 gigabits per second. The frequency provided by this technology is (24 GHz reaching to 72GHz) above the lower boundary of extremely high frequency. The enveloping area is divided into the regions called cells which are serviced by individualized antennas. The distinguishing factor of this emerging technology is the low latency results in providing the fixed bandwidth. It widely finds its application in various sectors such as in smart surveillance, monitoring tracking, automation, and many others. Strengths: 1. What do we do best? 2. What unique knowledge, talent, or resources do we have? 3. What advantages do we have? 4. What do other people say we do well? 5. What resources do we have available? 6. What is our greatest achievement? Weaknesses: 1. What could we improve? 2. What knowledge, talent, skills and/or resources are we lacking? 3. What disadvantages do we have? 4. What do other people say we don’t do well? 5. In what areas do we need more training? 6. What customer complaints have we had about our service? Opportunities: 1. How can we turn our strengths into opportunities? 2. How can we turn our weaknesses into opportunities? 3. Is there a need in our agency that no one is the meeting? 4. What could we do today that isn’t being done? 5. How is our field changing? How can we take advantage of those changes? 6. Who could we support? How could we support them? Threats: 1. What obstacles do we face? 2. Could any of our weaknesses prevent our unit from meeting our goals? 3. Who and/or what might cause us problems in the future? How? 4. Are there any standards, policies, and/or legislation changing that might negatively impact us? 5. Are we competing with others to provide service? 6. Are there changes in our field or in technology that could threaten our success?

While discussing the deployment of 5G networks, writers and bloggers often mention the initiatives taken by large telecom companies and network solution providers. But we should not forget that many small tech companies and startups also contribute immensely to simplify and speed up mass-scale 5G deployment. Simnovus – an Indian startup that has been helping device manufacturers to validate 5G devices and network operators to validate base stations by launching a slew of innovative solutions – UE Simulator and network emulators. Simnovator – the UE Simulator on COTS developed by Simnovus helps telecom companies to validate base stations without investing in expensive proprietary hardware. Many leading telecom companies already use Simnovator to perform feature and regression testing by running the tests on multiple test beds simultaneously. Likewise, Callbox – the network emulators on COTS developed by Simnovus – helps device manufacturers to validate 5G devices under varying network configurations. The device manufacturers can further use Callbox as a unified 5G device testing solution to validate multiple software versions, verify carrier aggregation, eliminate the need for drive testing, and identify device failures. The next-generation solutions like Simnovator and Callbox contribute immensely towards addressing the common challenges in 5G networks and device testing. The effectiveness of these 5G testing solutions can be assessed based on the fact that Simnovator is currently being used by a leading 5G stack provider like Radisys. Also, Callbox is currently being used by a leading manufacturer of ultra-rugged LTE handsets and mobile solutions like RSonim Tech. Hence, it is time to mention the small companies and startups while discussing the commercial deployment of 5G networks.

This question already have several useful responses and I will not attempt to outsmart them in a response but I would like to draw attention to the following thought process I often use when I analyze this type of topic:  1) The companies that are the most vocal is not always the once that are most advanced but rather the once that has most to win by portraying them self as market leaders.2) The companies not being very vocal can either be that because they have nothing to say and have no real position OR they have a very strong position that could only be hurt by being to vocal publicly.  With this said I would look for companies that might not be vocal or to active in (marketing) conferences but instead is active in 3GPP, NGMN, TM-Forum, (open or closed) 5G trials, 5G test beds etc. With this you can most probably identify a few extra companies in addition to the once mentioned below - two somewhat obvious large company examples is Qualcomm and Intel and a example of a smaller one is Nomor.  Make sure one does not confuse the marketing noise a company do with their relative competitive position in the development of a new technology such as 5G.

Reliance Jio is one of the leading telecom companies in the world and shall be offering not just 5G network for their 250 million subscribers, but also new smart devices that shall make use of 5G technology and other technologies like augmented reality, virtual reality, etc. in the coming years. Jio’s 5G infrastructure consists of chipsets, peripherals, etc. which are already 5G-ready. They are compatible for 5G devices and shall be available for their subscribers by the year 2020. As mentioned earlier, other smart devices that make use of 5G tech shall also be launched at very affordable prices for its users starting from 2021. In the recently held Indian Mobile Congress, Reliance Jio, partnering with Ericsson, showcased a live demo of what exactly 5G technology can bring to its users. A prototype driverless car at Reliance Corporate Park (RCP) in Mumbai was controlled using 5G technology from Aerocity grounds. This primarily demonstrates the efficiency and lower levels of latency which has the potential to connect entities in real time, irrespective of the distance. There were also surveillance drones on display and an aerial disaster management vehicle SKYSHIP, with facial recognition features for rescue activities. handling Director Sh. Mukesh Ambani had this to say on conference- By 2020, Asia will likely to be completely 4G connected, and by the period the united states would be ready for 5G connection besides. To conclude, Jio will probably be taking 5G technology to its users as soon as possible and tasks are currently underway to improve its infrastructure.

There are various ways to judge this: Press Releases, Patent filings, 3GPP contributions, demonstrations...Remember 3GPP has only just started even ther frameworks for 5G, so in some ways it is premature. But on the other hand, a huge amount of stuff has already been discussed & consensus reached. But my subjective opinion: HuaweiSamsungDoCoMoEricssonNokiaReal Wireless (*)Korea & China are being very active on national level. That includes the above companies, various other smaller ones and the research labs & universities. Japan is also keen - with the goal of being first to launch for the Olympics in summer 2020. But they have fewer OEMs, and it is still DocoMo who (rather uniquely for a carrier) is investing in R&D. Europe is active too: both with the OEMs and with national money (eg EU research and 5GPP initiative) While there are some specific exceptions (I like KUMU a lot, for example) in general USA is not doing anything like as much.  (*) A consultancy I am an associate with. They are participating in the NORMA program on 5G architecture.

It's not yet defined what the standard of "5G" will actually be in detail.If you look at the timeline shared by 3gpp earlier this year (Tentative 3GPP timeline for 5G), you see that so far, even most of the evaluations of 5G technologies for standardization have not started yet.   So if companies are talking (bragging) about trialing 5G in different areas of the world, or demonstrate some capabilities of 5G in lab environments, chances are high that they are not all talking about the same "5G", but their own idea of what 5G should be. That said, big players in proposing standards for 5G at the moment are surely Ericsson, Nokia, DoCoMo, Huawei and Samsung, with Huawei and Samsung pushing strongest, as they see a opportunity to "change the game" and become owner of the next generation networks.

5G (Fifth generation) wireless communication is next major phase of mobile communications standards beyond the current LTE-Advanced. In order to meet 5G faster speed (1-10 Gbps), millimeter wave frequency band has been recommended for 5G wireless communication. Ka band has been targeted for short-range, high data rate communication.According to Aicha Evans (the leader of Intel’s Communication and Devices Group) “I find 5G exciting not because of what we know about it, but rather what we don’t know about it. It will help us in improving our lifestyle.” Following companies are considered as leading in 5G technologies. 1. Nokia 2. Qualcomm 3. Ericsson 4. Sumsung 5. No company owns 5G. 5G is in the public Domain in a very real sense. The ITU-R, the radio section of the international telecommunications union has set up the service standard and the requirements. They also need to approve any technical standard for 5G compliance. Nobody else has got any rights to the 5G label. The ITU defines their standards based on research about current and future usage of a technology, and about technology advancement. International development organizations can design technical standards are submit them to ITU-R for approval. The only serious attempt is made by 3GPP, a worldwide consortium of regional members, tech companies and researchers. They have proposed their release R15 (just a count) for 5G. 3GPP includes members from Asia, Europe and the US.

They are being led by companies like Ericsson, Nokia, Huawei, Zte, Fujitsu etc from OEM side.  From Operator side, AT&T, Verizon, Teliasonera etc have MOU with OEM's. The 5G ecosystem comprises various players including chip manufacturers (Qualcomm and Intel), telecom and ISP providers (AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile), system suppliers (Huawei, Ericsson, Cisco, and Samsung), and other software, standards and material suppliers. Ericsson, Samsung, Huawei and Qualcomm seem to be leading the race which is evident from the number of patents filed by these companies surrounding 5G.

Some of the top leading companies would be Huawei (China), Ericsson (Sweden), STL(India), Samsung (South Korea), Nokia Networks (Finland), ZTE (China), NEC (Japan), CISCO (US), CommScope (US), Comba Telecom Systems (Hong Kong), Alpha Networks (Taiwan), Siklu Communication (Israel), and Mavenir (US). But accords to ITU-R no company owns 5G. 5G is in the public domain in a very real sense. with this said If we look for companies that might not be vocal or just not focusing on paid publicity but instead is active in 3GPP, NGMN, TM-Forum, (open or closed) 5G trials, 5G testbeds, etc., a company by the name of VVDN Technologies (based out of India) promises to be an emerging company in 5G. Recently they collaborated with STL for the manufacturing of 5G solutions. STL, VVDN Technologies join hands to develop and manufacture 5G solutions.

There are many countries working towards R&D of 5G communication. Standardization for 5G networks, devices, Technology is yet to be done by ITU. 5G- a 5th generation digital cellular network. The ability of 4G is to support up to 100,000 devices per square kilometer. On the contrary, 5G cellular network can support up to a million devices per square kilometer. 5G technology promises tremendous improvements in responsiveness, speed etc. The download speed of 5G is ~50 times faster than the existing 4GLTE technology. T-mobile, Verizon, AT&T, Rogers Wireless, Deutsche Telekom, EE, Vodafone Group, Telefonica, China Mobile, SK Telecom, Reliance Jio- are some of the top leading companies providing 5G technologies.
